title: Can Nuno, Edu and Evangelos Marinakis fix the mess at Nottingham Forest?
description: A typically tumultuous 72 hours raised questions over manager's future and doubts still linger over his long-term prospects
content:
As the equaliser went in, Nuno Espirito Santo’s coaching staff gathered around him.

It is something they do after every goal: celebrate as one. It is a show of togetherness and, perhaps more than ever, it is also the kind of unity Nottingham Forest’s head coach needs from elsewhere in the club.

Has it gone beyond that stage? Or is there any way to fix this mess, given that Nuno’s working relationship with Edu, the newly appointed global head of football for Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis’ multi-club empire, has got off to such an alarmingly bad start?

Nuno offered a glimpse into his own mindset before the 1-1 draw away to Crystal Palace on Sunday, when he confirmed he wanted to continue as Forest’s coach — some reports had questioned whether he was trying to engineer his own sacking — but accepted the three relevant people needed to get together to work this out.

That meant himself and Edu, principally, and Marinakis, too, as the man who could never have foreseen this drama when the Brazilian, formerly Arsenal’s sporting director, was announced in his new role on July 7.

It was after Sunday’s match, however, that we learnt more about what Nuno wants to happen next — “not only the three of us, all the club has to come together” – and his tone of voice went up for the first time.

It was, he said, an “absurd narrative” to think that his complaints behind the scenes might lead to him resigning in protest or wanting to be sacked. “Absolute nonsense, absurd, absurd … never!” he added, even more firmly, before referencing his admiration for a former Palace manager who was still managing at the highest level, at the age of 76, until last year.

“Roy Hodgson, chapeau! Every time I saw Roy working, I used to say: ‘Wow! Can I do the same?’ I wish I could,” said Nuno. “I don’t know how many years I have been coaching now. I love what I do. The moment I do not enjoy it” — at this, he blew out his cheeks — “it’s over.”

Yet Nuno, by his own admission, accepts that his job is in danger and admitted last week — “where there’s smoke, there’s fire” – that he suspected there was something in the reports that Marinakis was considering sacking him. So, is he really enjoying it?

“Of course, the situation has to be solved,” he said. “We are responsible people and we are going to have a good conversation to try, more than anything, to create a good platform for what is most important — the team.”

And that question again: can it be fixed? Can he and Edu make up and Forest return to the kind of positive atmosphere that was there, say, six months ago?

“I believe so,” said Nuno. “Everyone wants the best for Forest. Myself, the president (Marinakis), all the club — we want the best for Forest. During my career, this is the first time I have faced this situation and been asked these things, and it is not helpful. But I believe we have to create harmony. We need it.”

The strange thing, perhaps, was when Nuno went on to say he was willing to wait. If you thought he might want these talks to happen straight away, that would be wrong. Instead, he talked about the priority for Forest being to bring in three more signings — a goalkeeper and two full-backs — ahead of the transfer window closing next Monday, September 1.

After that, he said, they could hold the relevant talks: “We need to have these conversations, and we are going to have them. This is what I think is more important than anything. The players need it, the squad needs it, the club needs it, we need it. And we are going to have it.”

And did he feel offended, after everything he has achieved with Forest since his December 2023 appointment, that suddenly his job seemed to be on the line? “This is how football is. There are things I cannot control. What comes out, the sacking (story), I cannot control.”

Before heading over to the Forest fans at Selhurst Park to applaud their support after the final whistle, Nuno made a beeline to Morgan Gibbs-White to put an arm around the player’s shoulder and explain why he had taken him off with eight minutes plus stoppage time left to find a winner.

The bond between Nuno and his team is a close one and, as he acknowledged, over the past few days there has been a lot of understandable confusion for those players.

His instruction to them was to block it all out and focus on the game. Yet Sunday’s draw, secured by Callum Hudson-Odoi’s second-half equaliser, took place amid a backdrop of reports stating that Brendan Rodgers, the Celtic manager, or Ange Postecoglou, fired by Tottenham Hotspur earlier this summer, were in the running to replace him. Who could be surprised if the mood in the dressing room had been more subdued than usual?

“We speak every day,” Nuno said of his players. “Focus, determination, ignore the noise — this was our message. They are human beings, and everything that happens affects us. But we were able to shield them.

“I have known some of these players since they were 16 years old. What we did last season together (chasing Champions League qualification before finishing seventh to end up in the Europa League — Forest’s first time in Europe since the mid-1990s) will stick forever in our memories. So this is the responsibility we have to our club: ignore the noise and work hard. And the boys did it well. I hope we can do it again next week; I hope I can do it again next week.”

Nuno was subsequently asked whether there had been any contact with Marinakis or Edu since the manager’s public conference last Friday exposed the divide.

“They were here today,” he said. Edu watched from the stands but Marinakis was conspicuous by his absence on a day Palace fans made it clear they blame Forest’s owner, in part, for their FA Cup winners being demoted from the Europa League place they secured by beating Manchester City at Wembley in May to the third-tier UEFA Conference League.

Some travelling Forest supporters had come to south London prepared with Marinakis masks. Others wore T-shirts celebrating the Greek billionaire. “Marinakis, he does what he wants,” went the song.

At the same time, there was also a sense of unease among the away fans – and perhaps also an uncomfortable feeling of deja vu, given the uncertainty around Nuno is not the first time they have had to endure this kind of turbulence in the eight-year Marinakis era.

In the 2018-19 season, Aitor Karanka was managing Forest in the Championship and popular enough with the public that a #dontsackaitor hashtag was trending on Twitter when it became clear something had gone wrong in his relationship with the club’s hierarchy.

Karanka, like Nuno, had grievances with one of the people above him, in his case Ioannis Vrentzos, then the chief executive and still a director at the club, though he’s now based in Greece.

As a former Real Madrid player and assistant coach, Karanka had experienced the high politics of life at the Bernabeu. At Forest, though, it wore him down. His wife stopped attending matches because of the atmosphere and, ultimately, he decided enough was enough. In the end, Karanka asked to be released from his contract, even though Forest were just one place outside the play-off positions at the time.

Six years on, Nuno was asked yesterday whether he was confident he would still be the Forest coach come the end of this transfer window next Monday.

“I cannot answer that question,” he replied. “But what I know is that I am trying to do my job the best I can.”

summary: NotNotNotEven Nottingham Forest's head coach, Nuno Espirito Santo, has been under pressure from his working relationship with Edu, the global head of football for Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis' multi-club empire, after a poor start. Nuno, who confirmed his intention to continue as Forest’s coach before the 1-1 draw away to Crystal Palace, accepted the need for a united front for the club. Edu, formerly Arsenal's sporting director, was announced in his new role on July 7 and has been tasked with creating a positive atmosphere for the team. Despite these issues, Nuntos acknowledged that his job was in danger and that he suspected there was something in the reports that Marinakis was considering sacking him.
shortSummary: Nuno Espirito Santo's Nottingham Forest team needs unity between him, Edu, and Evangelos Marinakis to fix their strained relationship, despite Nuno's insistence on continuing as coach.

scraped_sources.text:
The question every Nottingham Forest fan would like answering is: how has it come to this? And the answer goes back to the appointment earlier this summer that owner Evangelos Marinakis believed would help take the club to the next level.
When Marinakis announced the appointment of Edu, formerly Arsenal’s sporting director, as Forest’s new transfer guru, he was entitled to think of it as a significant coup for a club their size. Just check out the wording of the official announcement. Forest were “proud” to confirm Edu’s arrival, read the club’s statement — not just pleased, or delighted, but proud.
Nottingham Forest is proud to announce the appointment of Edu Gaspar as Global Head of Football, a newly established leadership role overseeing football operations.
— Nottingham Forest (@NFFC) July 7, 2025
Unfortunately for Forest, one man was not quite so enamoured: Nuno Espirito Santo, the manager who has led Forest back into Europe for the first time in 30 years and, unreported until now, has had a spectacular fallout with Edu behind the scenes.
Nuno’s relationship with Edu started badly and, since then, it has deteriorated to the point where there is an acceptance at the City Ground that the damage is potentially irreparable. Edu arrived with Kia Joorabchian, the influential businessman and football advisor, as his close ally. The manager has made his feelings clear, particularly about Edu, both to the man himself and others at the club.
Advertisement
It is personal, deeply personal, between himself and Edu and perhaps the most worrying aspect for Forest fans is that, as things stand, it is difficult to see the two men making up. Of the two, Nuno has largely been the aggressor, outspoken in the extreme. Edu has been staying away from the club’s training ground.
This has been bubbling away for the past two months and has clearly put Marinakis in a difficult position, to say the least, when two of the most important people at the club are not even on speaking terms.
On the one hand, Nuno is a highly respected and popular coach who has come to be adored by the club’s supporters and was widely touted last season as a potential winner of manager-of-the-year awards.
Don’t forget that Nuno also signed a new contract on June 20, two and a half weeks before Edu was confirmed as the global head of football for Marinakis’ empire — Forest, Greek club Olympiacos and Portuguese team Rio Ave. Marinakis saw the Brazilian as a brilliant appointment and expected his manager to adapt to a new working environment.
So what does Marinakis do when it becomes clear Nuno has taken against Edu and, even more troublingly, has suddenly chosen to direct his anger — or at least part of it — towards the club during a series of deliberately aggressive press-conference statements?
First of all, let’s go back to Nuno’s interview with Sky on Wednesday last week when he went public for the first time about his grievances with the club’s recruitment over the summer.
Forest, he said, had a “major problem”. It had been a bad pre-season, Nuno continued, expressing his irritation about how long everything was taking to come together. He talked about being “worried” and described Forest as “very, very far” from where they needed to be.
Nuno did not mention Edu by name. Everyone, however, at the top level of the club, from Marinakis down, knew who it was directed towards — and that there was more to it than just the club’s transfer business.
Advertisement
That interview was not supposed to be out until the weekend (though parts of it were released on Friday) and it was not a coincidence that Forest suddenly stepped up their transfer activity on Thursday and Friday.
Omari Hutchinson arrived from Ipswich Town in a club-record £37.5million transfer, followed by striker Arnaud Kalimuendo from French club Rennes and Manchester City’s James McAtee. Then, on Thursday evening, Douglas Luiz arrived on loan from Juventus, with an obligation to buy.
In doing so, the PR narrative changed considerably from what it would have been had Nuno’s comments gone out before the flurry of new signings. Everything had been overtaken and, while Nuno’s comments were obviously concerning, the good news outweighed the bad. Or that, at least, was how it would have seemed to anyone not understanding the politics behind the scenes.
In reality, the rift still existed.
Marinakis, moreover, could probably be forgiven for taking Nuno’s comments personally, given how generous the Forest owner has been, financially, when it comes to transfer spend.
It is no exaggeration to say Forest were stunned by Nuno’s comments — not just what he said, but the fact he looked visibly angry — and his timing to go public in this way for an interview that was meant to go out 24 hours before their first game of the season.
As it turned out, the mood was soothed by Forest’s 3-1 win over Brentford and a performance that suggested Nuno’s team might be in for another exciting season. Again, though, nothing has changed in the context of how Nuno sees Edu and the wider effect it is having on the club.
At his latest press conference, Nuno described his relationship with Marinakis as having changed and went public that they were “not so close” anymore. And that, in a nutshell, is because Marinakis has aligned himself with Edu.
Advertisement
“I have always had a very good relationship with the owner,” said Nuno. “Last season was very, very close, (we spoke) almost on a daily basis. This season, not so well. I always believed that dialogue and what you say, or your opinions, are always valid. Because my concern is the squad and the season that we have ahead of us.
“Our relationship has changed. It’s not so close. It’s not on a daily basis. It’s not good, everyone at the club should be together but it’s not the reality.”
For context, this follows a concerted attempt by the club to pour cold water on reports from abroad, starting early on Friday, that Marinakis was considering sacking him. Instead, Nuno chose to go public again, surely knowing that Marinakis would take it as a personal affront. When asked about the reports, the 51-year-old replied: “Where there’s smoke, there’s fire, so I know how things work, but I’m here to do my job.”
Being a manager in the Marinakis empire is a challenging job, as Steve Cooper and various others can testify. Behind the scenes at Forest, there is often conflict at the highest level. Some of the people who have been prominently involved since Marinakis’ takeover in 2017 positively encourage it.
At the same time, this is a troubling situation for everyone at the City Ground and the speed at which relations have unravelled, or started to unravel, has been startling. And to a degree, it is easy to sympathise with Marinakis on this occasion. Plainly, he could never have realised that Nuno would take against the new man from virtually day one. Yet, at the very first meeting, there were hostilities. It blew up almost immediately.
Are there more politics involved? Nuno is represented by Jorge Mendes, who at one stage could legitimately be described as Marinakis’ go-to agent in the transfer market.
Yet Mendes has not been involved in any Forest transfer since Eric da Silva Moreira arrived from St. Pauli in June 2024, and these days it is very much an operation that has Joorabchian at the heart of what they do.
Advertisement
Joorabchian, an Iranian-born businessman, is best known for looking after Carlos Tevez during the Argentine’s brilliant yet often controversial playing career, including spells with West Ham United, Manchester United and Manchester City.
Joorabchian has had a string of other top-level clients and was closely involved in the past with Everton, Reading and Manchester City. He also represents Hutchinson and Douglas Luiz and was partly involved in the deal that saw Anthony Elanga move to Newcastle United for £52m earlier this summer.
Edu sees him as a close ally, and so does Marinakis. In the last year or so, Joorabchian has become increasingly involved with Marinakis in a number of business interests, spending millions of pounds on racehorses with associates that include the Greek billionaire.
Has that put Mendes’ nose out of joint? Possibly, but The Athletic’s information is that Mendes plays no significant part in the latest drama and it is far more the case that Nuno views his relationship with Edu as broken. Joorabchian is a big part of the modern Forest, but it all starts with the Nuno-Edu dynamic — what should be the second most important relationship within the club.
Can it be fixed? Every Forest fan would hope so, and every player, too, because it is undoubtedly the case that Nuno is popular within the dressing room.
For now, though, this is a story of politics, tension, male pride and suspicion that has suddenly propelled Nuno to the top of the bookmakers’ lists when it comes to the next Premier League manager to be sacked. It is also the case that questions are being asked about whether Friday morning’s reports of a potential sacking were leaked deliberately to crank everything up just before Nuno’s weekly press conference.
It is not a healthy situation and, one week into the new Premier League season, the supporters who have grown to love Nuno must be shocked by how quickly in football — and Forest, in particular — the mood can change.
(Top pictures: Getty Images)

Nuno Espirito Santo has said his relationship with Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis has changed since last season and the two are “not so close” anymore.
The Forest head coach’s comments come a week after he said the club have a “major problem” after the summer window and were “very, very far” from where they need to be.
Advertisement
Following Nuno’s comments, Forest completed four transfers: the club-record signing of Omari Hutchinson from Ipswich Town, forward Arnaud Kalimuendo from Rennes, Manchester City’s James McAtee and Douglas Luiz, on loan with an obligation to buy, from Juventus.
They were added to the earlier summer arrivals of Dan Ndoye, Igor Jesus, Jair Cunha and Angus Gunn.
However, despite these moves and the opening-weekend 3-1 home victory over Brentford, Nuno has said his relationship with Marinakis is no longer the same.
“I have always had a very good relationship with the owner, last season was very, very close, almost on a daily basis,” Nuno said on Friday, via Sky, ahead of his side’s visit to Crystal Palace this weekend.
“This season, not so well. I always believed that dialogue and what you say, or your opinions, are always valid. Because my concern is the squad and the season that we have ahead of us.
“Our relationship has changed. It’s not so close. It’s not on a daily basis. It’s not good, everyone at the club should be together but it’s not the reality.”
When asked if the working relationship could continue, Nuno said: “I hope so but I don’t know, that I cannot answer. On my side I am doing whatever I can to help Forest, my commitment is something (that I see) and I feel it.”
Nuno added “where there’s smoke, there’s fire” in response to suggestions his role at the club is under threat. “We know each other very well, and we have all been in the industry for a while now,” he said, via Reuters.
“And where there’s smoke, there’s fire, so I know how things work, but I’m here to do my job. I understand, because I’m worried. I’m the first one to be worried. I’m the first one to be concerned.”
This is Forest’s first transfer window following the arrival of new global head of football Edu, who officially joined on July 7 after leaving his role as sporting director at Arsenal in November last year.
Advertisement
Global head of football is a newly created position that sees the 47-year-old oversee “recruitment, performance, squad strategy, and player development.”
Nuno has been at Forest since December 2023, when he replaced Steve Cooper as head coach. After finishing 17th in 2023-24, the Portuguese oversaw a seventh-place finish last season which secured a return to European football for the first time since 1995.
(Justin Tallis/AFP via Getty Images)

The English FA will investigate a banner displayed by Crystal Palace fans showing Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis holding a gun to the head of midfielder Morgan Gibbs-White.
The banner was displayed in the Lower Holmesdale Stand, where the Holmesdale Fanatics supporters’ group sits, at Selhurst Park during Sunday’s Premier League game between the sides. It was not shown during Sky Sports’ UK broadcast of the match.
Advertisement
On the banner, Gibbs-White is shown with a speech bubble next to him reading: “Mr Marinakis is not involved in blackmail, match-fixing, drug trafficking or corruption!”
Marinakis has always strongly denied any wrongdoing in relation to these allegations.
As well as Gibbs-White, the banner also depicts Marinakis holding a briefcase overflowing with cash; what appears to be a UEFA delegate standing behind bags which read “correspondence” with the UEFA and Forest badges on; former Palace minority shareholder John Textor as a clown; and a ship with Marinakis’ name on — the Greek businessman is the founder and chairman of Capital Maritime & Trading Corp.
On the Palace website, in a statement which ends with “Published by The Football Association Premier League Limited”, the club say, “Banners must not contain foul language, be defamatory or contain political or offensive slogans and the club reserves the right to turn banners away if the content is felt to be offensive in any way.”
When contacted by The Athletic, the Premier League indicated the incident was a matter for the FA. Palace and Forest were approached for comment. The Holmesdale Fanatics declined to comment.
Ahead of the game, Palace said on social media that they “would like to remind supporters that acts of discrimination, including inappropriate chanting, violence and entering the field of play, will not be tolerated at Selhurst Park”.
Gibbs-White signed a new contract at Forest in late July, having been the subject of bids from Tottenham Hotspur and appearing set to have a medical at the north London club. The Athletic reported that Gibbs-White had a key 30-minute meeting with Marinakis before committing his future to Forest until 2028.
Tensions between Palace and Forest have grown over the summer after the former was demoted from the Europa League to the Conference League — with the latter promoted as a result — having been found to have breached UEFA’s multi-club ownership rules. UEFA’s decision to demote Palace was upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) earlier this month.
Advertisement
In 2021, a banner displayed at Selhurst Park by the Holmesdale Fanatics was the subject of a police investigation. That banner was on display when Newcastle United faced Palace, shortly after the north-east club’s takeover, which was largely funded by the Saudi Arabian Public Investment Fund (PIF). The banner took aim at the Premier League’s owners’ and directors’ test, and the Croydon Metropolitan Police said it had been reported as “offensive”.
Explaining the Palace-Forest tensions
In the aftermath of Palace’s demotion, their chairman Steve Parish did a round of media interviews in which he intimated that someone else had been behind the punishment.
“We’re led to believe that’s the issue,” said on The Rest Is Football podcast, when asked by host Gary Lineker if Forest had “played a part” in the process. “If there wasn’t someone who wanted to get in as a consequence, then there wouldn’t be a problem.”
This was in reference to a letter that Forest had written to UEFA about the issue, which they have always insisted was a matter of them simply seeking clarity about which competition they would be in this season, so they could plan accordingly. Forest also say the letter was sent when UEFA was already investigating Palace’s status amid a crackdown on these rules, which had already seen European football’s governing body kick Irish side Drogheda United and Slovakia’s DAC 1904 out of the Conference League for similar breaches.
Nevertheless, Forest’s owner Marinakis, along with former Palace minority shareholder John Textor — whose controlling stake in French side Lyon had been the trigger for Palace’s demotion — and UEFA, became the focus of Palace fans’ ire.
At their first three games of this season — the Community Shield at Wembley, the goalless Premier League draw away to Chelsea and the first leg at home against Fredrikstad — Palace fans displayed a banner with the words ‘UEFA MAFIA’ on a version of the body’s logo with a Euro symbol replacing the map of Europe, and also chanted “F*** UEFA, f*** John Textor, f*** Marinakis.” It’s clear who they blame for the situation, and it’s not anybody in the current Palace hierarchy.
(Top photo: Richard Pelham/Getty Images)

Nottingham Forest head coach Nuno Espirito Santo has denied he wants to leave the club — but admitted that his relationships with global head of football Edu and owner Evangelos Marinakis need to improve.
As revealed by The Athletic on Friday, Nuno’s relationship with Edu — who officially joined Forest on July 7, having stepped down as Arsenal director of football — has deteriorated to the point where the damage is potentially irreparable.
Edu has been staying away from the club’s training ground amid a deeply personal rift between the pair, who have clashed over the club’s summer transfer business.
Nuno also admitted at his latest press conference that his relationship with Marinakis has worsened since last season.
Asked by Sky Sports ahead of Forest’s visit to Crystal Palace on Sunday if communication with Edu and Marinakis needed to improve, Nuno said: “Yes. That’s what we need to do and we’re going to do it.
Advertisement
“Today for sure not, because it’s the match. But soon of course. There’s no speculation around anything. What we have (to do) is to communicate and approach the final days of the market how we’re going to approach the season (and) prepare our boys.”
At a news conference after Sunday’s 1-1 draw, Nuno was asked if he was confident he would still be at Forest come the end of the transfer window.
“I cannot answer that question,” he replied. “But what I know is that I am working and trying to do my job the best I can.”
When asked if he thought the situation could get back to being harmonious, the head coach said: “I believe so. Everyone wants the best for Forest. Myself, the president, all the club… we want the best for Forest.
“I believe we have to create harmony. We need it.”
Speaking last week, Nuno admitted his relationship with Marinakis had “changed” and was not “so close” as last season, when he said they spoke every day.
Those comments came a week after he said his “unbalanced” side had a “major problem” ahead of the start of the new season, and were “very, very far” from where they need to be.
Nuno’s recent outspokenness has led to suggestions that he is trying to engineer a way out of the City Ground, which he strongly denied on Sunday.
“That’s nonsense, that doesn’t make any kind of sense,” the Portuguese said. “The state is that we’re focussed on the game. That’s more important. We have to make sure the players are ready to play. This game is going to be very tough.”
Pushed on whether he definitely wanted to continue, he replied: “Of course. Of course.”
Forest completed four transfers since Nuno claimed they had a “major problem”: the club-record signing of Omari Hutchinson from Ipswich Town, Arnaud Kalimuendo from Rennes, Manchester City’s James McAtee and Douglas Luiz, on loan with an obligation to buy, from Juventus.
Advertisement
They were added to the earlier summer arrivals of Dan Ndoye, Igor Jesus, Jair Cunha and Angus Gunn.
Global head of football is a newly created position at Forest that sees Edu, 47, oversee “recruitment, performance, squad strategy, and player development”.
Nuno has been at Forest since December 2023, when he replaced Steve Cooper as head coach. After finishing 17th in 2023-24, Nuno oversaw a seventh-place finish last season which secured a return to European football for the first time since 1995.
He signed a new three-year contract in June.
(Top photo: Richard Pelham/Getty Images)

argos_summary: Nottingham Forest manager Nuno Espirito Santo has publicly acknowledged a strained relationship with new global head of football Edu and owner Evangelos Marinakis, insisting the club must restore harmony to avoid jeopardising his job. Despite rumours of a potential sacking, Nuno reaffirmed his commitment to the team, citing recent high-profile signings and a desire to focus on performance rather than politics. The tension highlights the challenges of balancing managerial autonomy with the ownership’s strategic ambitions within the club’s evolving structure.
